title: Aspiration
transcript:
NARRATOR: American After the Fall, “Aspiration” by Aaron Douglas. And to the left “American Justice” by Joe Jones, 1933.

SARAH KELLY OEHLER: Aaron Douglas was an African-American artist, and like many others at this time, he felt that African-Americans were not being represented in every day histories of the United States. But he also felt that it was important to represent them in a positive light. Now the entire painting has been done in this very modern style. It’s an extraordinary work of art. The three figures at center are contemporary men and a woman who hold the tools of their educational training. And they’re looking towards an industrial city on a hill. Below them are hands reaching up and those hands have been manacled.

Sarah Kelly Oehler: Douglas is reflecting on the history of slavery in the United States and how all of the aspirations of current generations of African-Americans is built upon a history of slavery, that still needs to be overcome. But can be overcome as he suggests in these paintings.

Judy Barter: The late twenties and thirties there was a great deal of migration from the South of African-Americans to cities in the north, to Los Angeles, to Detroit, to Chicago. They were in constant debt. They couldn’t own their land and so they left for a better life. And that’s what “Aspiration” is about.
